abstract.p: Lucy Atkin letter on May 11 article hails Pres Clinton's move to increase access to AIDS drugs in sub-Saharan Africa; proposes other steps to curb spread of AIDS

block.p: President Clinton must be applauded for his move to increase access of AIDS-related drugs in sub-Saharan Africa (news article, May 11).

Although more than 70 percent of all people with AIDS live in sub-Saharan Africa, only 1 percent of all AIDS medication is sold in that region. Without access to medical treatment, the 23 million people in the area living with H.I.V. or AIDS have little reason to disclose their status or even be tested, and little incentive to take part in safer practices and community outreach initiatives.
President Clinton must be applauded for his move to increase access of AIDS-related drugs in sub-Saharan Africa (news article, May 11).

Although more than 70 percent of all people with AIDS live in sub-Saharan Africa, only 1 percent of all AIDS medication is sold in that region. Without access to medical treatment, the 23 million people in the area living with H.I.V. or AIDS have little reason to disclose their status or even be tested, and little incentive to take part in safer practices and community outreach initiatives.

Affordable medication is one of the keys to breaking this cycle. However, international family planning and sexuality education programs must be expanded along with continued efforts to strengthen overburdened health and education systems, overcome extreme poverty and associated ills that plague the region.
LUCY ATKIN Dir., Margaret Sanger Center Intl. Planned Parenthood of N.Y.C. New York, May 12, 2000
